Award.AwardTitle: SHF: SMALL: Effective and Equitable Technical Interviews in Software Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the software industry, a software engineer must pass a series of technical evaluations, called technical interviews, when applying for a job. A popular form of the technical interview requires software engineers to write computer code on the spot in front of interviewers. There are industry-wide concerns that such interviews may lack real-world relevance and be ineffective at evaluating technical competencies, while introducing systemic bias and unnecessary stress. This project aims to develop technical evaluations of software-engineering proficiency that are more equitable. The main objective is to enable broadening participation in the software-engineering workforce. To achieve this objective, the research investigates software-engineering processes involving human judgment of code, such as during code reviews.

This project will develop techniques to measure the technical performance of a programming task and identify factors that negatively impact the ability to write code, such as high cognitive load, poor affective state, and limited affordances. Three main research tasks will be investigated for this project. The first task will involve data mining technical-interview experiences and engagement with stakeholders in order to determine a comprehensive list of factors concerning technical evaluation of code. The second task will involve a series of randomized, controlled trials to establish the effects of various conditions, such as problem-solving complexity, use of concurrent think-aloud, and presence of stereotype threat on technical performance. The third task will involve the development of interventions that reduce unwanted effects on technical performance, such as retrospective think-aloud or private interviews, and will include evaluating trials in industry. Overall, this project connects to the stream of research on identifying opportunities for increasing equity in software engineering and information work: improving diversity and tenure of teams and providing resources for disadvantaged and low-resource job seekers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to improve the fairness and effectiveness of technical interviews in software engineering, addressing critical challenges related to inclusivity and bias. Throughout the award period, we examined various dynamics, including recruitment, collaboration, and the influence of emerging technologies. Our goal was to design innovative interventions and enhance assessment practices, making the hiring process more equitable and efficient.

Understanding the Impact of Think-Aloud in Technical Interviews: A key focus of the project was investigating how think-aloud techniques influence performance in technical interviews. While think-alouds offer interviewers valuable insights into a candidate's problem-solving process, they often hinder effective communication due to performance anxiety. To address this challenge, we introduced asynchronous interviews in which candidates submitted recordings of their think-aloud and coding. By eliminating the pressure of live supervision, candidates were able to communicate more clearly. Our findings showed that this approach not only improved candidates' communication but also led to better overall performance and significantly clearer think-alouds compared to traditional technical interviews.

Inclusive Recruitment Framework: One of the project's major achievements was the development of an inclusive recruitment framework to help overcome barriers faced by underrepresented groups in Human-Centered Software Engineering (HCSE). Through interviews with 20 professionals in the field, we identified 25 key barriers to inclusive recruitment and devised 20 actionable strategies. These strategies, categorized into five themes—participant skepticism, study design limitations, logistical constraints, gatekeeping, and researcher well-being—are designed to help researchers implement more inclusive practices, ultimately improving participant diversity in HCSE studies and promoting better representation within the field.

Gender and Race Dynamics in Pair Programming: The project also examined how gender and race affect collaboration and performance during remote pair programming. In studies with 24 experienced developers in same-gender and mixed-gender and racial pairs, we uncovered significant insights into team dynamics. For instance, women-women pairs exhibited strong decision-making but lower productivity compared to men-men pairs, while mixed-race pairs demonstrated higher productivity and more equitable task-sharing, despite facing communication challenges. These findings suggest the need for more inclusive practices and tools to support diverse teams, ensuring that differences in collaboration styles do not hinder performance.

Impact of Large Language Models (LLMs) on Software Engineering: As emerging technologies like Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly integrated into software development, the project explored their potential impact on technical interviews and broader workflows. Interviews with 16 professional developers revealed that tools such as ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot are valuable for tasks like code generation and debugging, but challenges remain, particularly in ensuring content accuracy. Our research highlights the transformative potential of LLMs for software development, particularly in technical assessments, while also pointing out areas where further improvements are needed to ensure their reliable integration into real-world applications.

Training and Professional Development

This project provided significant training opportunities for students, offering hands-on research experience in software engineering and human-computer interaction. Four undergraduate students and two junior high school students actively contributed to the project, gaining valuable exposure to research methodologies and software development practices. Additionally, two Ph.D. students played key roles in analyzing technical interviews, gender and race dynamics, and inclusive recruitment practices in software engineering, advancing their academic careers. The Principal Investigators (PIs) also disseminated research findings at major conferences and delivered talks at universities worldwide, fostering professional engagement and facilitating knowledge sharing across the academic and industry communities.

Dissemination and Broader Impacts

The results of this project were widely disseminated through academic conferences, and journals. These efforts reached a broad audience of academics, industry professionals, and organizations focused on diversity, collaboration, and innovation in software engineering. The PI also gave talks at universities globally, spreading insights on inclusivity and the role of emerging technologies in software development.

The broader impact of this project lies in its potential to reshape hiring practices and team collaboration in software engineering. By addressing inclusivity in technical assessments and everyday collaboration, the project contributes to fostering a more diverse and equitable workforce. Additionally, the exploration of emerging technologies like LLMs offers a vision for how these tools can improve efficiency and innovation in the field, benefiting both developers and organizations.
